Understate: The claim understates Carson's involvement with Mannatech by stating that he "didn't have an involvement with them" when evidence suggests otherwise.
Lack enough support: The claim lacks enough support to prove that Carson had no involvement with Mannatech, as there is evidence of speeches and promotional work done for the company.
Problematic assumption: The claim makes the problematic assumption that Carson's speeches and promotional work for Mannatech can be seen as a full endorsement of the product.
Exist alternative explanation: There is an alternative explanation that Carson's speeches and promotional work for Mannatech can be seen as a form of endorsement, as the company views him as a product promoter.
Contradict fact: The claim contradicts the fact that Carson did have a 10-year relationship with Mannatech, as stated by the moderator in the Republican presidential debate.
Exaggerate: The claim exaggerates the extent of Carson's involvement with Mannatech by stating that he was an employee, when there is no evidence to support this.
Falters at times: The claim falters at times by not providing a clear and consistent explanation of Carson's involvement with Mannatech.
